story:
No Idea Festival 2012:: noideafestival.com

Celebrating its ninth year of activity, No Idea Festival 2012 brings together a select group of musicians and inter-media artists from across the US and Europe for several nights of collaboration. Events will be held in Austin, San Antonio and Houston, Texas between February 02-06, 2012.

Featured artists include:
Andrea Neumann -- inside piano, electronics (Berlin)
Bonnie Jones -- electronics, text (Baltimore)
Bhob Rainey -- saxophone (New Orleans)
Greg Kelley -- trumpet (Boston)
Jason Lescalleet -- tapes, electronics (Maine)
Chris Cogburn -- percussion, electronics (Austin)
Bryan Eubanks -- electronics (NYC)
Vic Rawlings -- prepared cello, surface electronics (Boston)
Maggie Bennett -- dance, constructions (NYC)
Nick Hennies -- percussion (Austin)
Rick Reed -- electronics (Austin)
Gill ArnÃ² -- slide projectors, electronics (NYC)

No Idea Festival History::
Initiated in 2003, No Idea Festival is an annual festival of improvised music featuring a handful of US's premiere creative musicians in collaboration with artists from around the world. No Idea aspires to connect contemporary sound artists, curators and audience, providing the space and time where artistic process can flourish, leading towards new areas and approaches in the music. No Idea events have taken place in several cities including: Austin, Houston, San Antonio, Marfa, Dallas, Fort Worth, New Orleans, Mexico City and MÃ©rida, YucatÃ¡n.

What This Campaign Is Supporting::
The No Idea 2012 Indiegogo Campaign is raising money to assist with fundamental travel expenses and logistics associated with hosting the festival in its base (Austin) and moving it to two other cities (San Antonio, Houston).

The funding you are providing supports:

  • Artist Travel: Getting artists to Texas! (airfare)
  • Travel Between Cities: Car rental, fuel
  • Venue Rental: Austin, San Antonio and Houston

The Indiegogo campaign supports the nuts + bolts of No Idea 2012 and assists greatly in expanding the festival's programming to our beloved sister cities (San Antonio + Houston). Meeting our 2012 Indiegogo goal of $2000, we can dedicate the majority of our prior fundraising efforts to artist fees, lodging and other expenses while keeping ticket fees affordable for students, artists and others.

Contributor Benefits::
Contributors will receive a number of special benefits including: concert admission, a festival pass, a special addition No Idea Festival 2012 silk-screened poster by artist Noel Waggener (artist/ designer of Revenant's Albert Ayler Box Set), inclusion in a special No Idea raffle (featuring signed cds from festival artists and Bhob Rainey's new book Manual, free acupuncture, massage, piano tuning and more!), limited edition Jason Lescalleet mixtape, invitation to a special lunch with No Idea artists sponsored by Ruby's BBQ in Austin and post-concert receptions in San Antonio and Houston, and much more..!

No Idea 2012 is funded and supported in part by the City of Austin through the Cultural Contracts Division. Further funding is provided by Meet The Composer's MetLife Creative Connections program and the Goethe Institut. Building upon this funding, it is our intention to draw upon the support of audience, fans and friends from Austin, San Antonio and Houston (and around the world), to help make No Idea 2012 a success and to help expand the programming into several new areas.

New Programming for No Idea 2012::

  • Artist Residency Program
    Several artists will be in residence in Austin the week prior to No Idea 2012, developing site-specific work, teaching workshops and recording together and with local musicians.
  • Workshops/ Education
    Expanding our educational programming, Boston sound artist Vic Rawlings will hold a two-day teaching residency at the Texas School For The Blind and Visually Impaired.
    Rawlings and NYC sound artist Bryan Eubanks will teach a one-day workshop at UT San Antonio.
    Sound artists Andrea Neumann and Bonnie Jones will hold a one-day public workshop in Austin co-sponsored by Switched-On.
  • Inter-Media Work
    Musician Chris Cogburn and dancer Maggie Bennett will co-curate No Idea 2012's opening night in Austin with their inter-media work "Artistic Practice As Curatorial Conversation".
  • Commissioned Work
    Austin percussionist and composer Nick Hennies will present a work for vibraphone and ensemble written especially for No Idea 2012.


Other Ways You Can Help::
Help us spread the word about No Idea 2012 and this supplemental fundraising campaign! Link to this page via Facebook and Twitter. Talk to friends, colleagues and family and please feel free to contact us with questions about volunteering your time and energy or donating resources (transportation (car, van), housing, etc.).

- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -

Raffle Info::
Raffle awards include:
-- Free copy of Bhob Rainey's Manual book on the BSC
-- One copy from a selection of CDs by participating No Idea artists including Nick Hennies, Bhob Rainey, Jason Lescalleet, Greg Kelley, Vic Rawlings, Andrea Neumann, Bonnie Jones and Gill ArnÃ².
-- $20 Gift Certificate from DOMY Books (in Austin + Houston)
-- $25 Sound Exchange Gift Certificate (Houston)
-- $25 End Of An Ear Gift Certificate (Austin)
-- Special CD and Poetry Chapbook package from Kendra Steiner Editions
-- Free one-hour massage (Austin: Julie Nathanielsz + Eleanor Harris)
-- Free acupuncture session at South Austin Community Acupuncture
-- Free admission to an Epistrophy Arts concert during their 2012 season
-- Free Piano Tuning by Cook's Piano Service
-- More awards TBA

** Note: The raffle will take place January 25, 2012. Awards will be announced that day via email. Please include your email address with purchase and let us know if you'd like to be entered in prizes specific to a city (Austin, Houston, San Antonio) or everything in the general raffle. Purchase of raffle ticket does not guarantee an award.

Reception Info::
Austin: Ruby's BBQ 4pm, Saturday, February 04
Houston: Location TBA, Sunday, February 05 (post-concert reception)
San Antonio: Location TBA, Monday, February 06 (post-concert-reception)

Please direct any questions to: chriscogburn [at] gmail [dot] com

story:
The Gemini Project

Heya! Fáilte, Halito, and Osiyo!  My name is KeL and I am the lead singer for the group, The Gemini Project.  I also have the privilege of co-producing The Gemini Project’s first full length studio album, Ceallach, wherein I get to play piano, guitar, bodhran, Native American hand drum, harmonica, and accordion on many of our tracks…because, you know, the other guys agreed to just let me. ;)  I’m of Irish, Choctaw, and Cherokee descent (in that order) and a little bit of Muscogee (Creek.)  Most of my singing has been in gospel choirs in church but I do the occasional live performance in an Irish pub or a cantina here and there.  No matter the venue, I always like to try expressing many facets of my cultural heritage in my singing and vocal styles.  I hope that you will enjoy hearing some of them on our new album, Ceallach, which will be released this summer.  :)

The Gemini Project officially began in 2006 with just two members, Jim and I (get it, Jim and I…Gemini?  haha!)  Now we are a group of six frightfully ego-less musicians committed to playing our kind of music for the benefit of the greater good.  We are very realistic about ourselves and what we hope to achieve; none of us are looking to get rich or make it big, we just love making music!  Jim, our other album co-producer and lead guitarist, has been writing and playing music for guitar for over twenty-five years and likewise for Native American flute for six years.  Jim donates most of his Native American flute cd’s to ONESpirit (nativeprogress.org) the proceeds of which are given to the Lakota of Pine Ridge Rez.  Jim and I were already considering making a Celtic album for quite some time.  Then, when I was visiting home, I got the call from my cousin Nicholas about our friend Rusty.  At that moment, I knew we had to make this album and why.

Not too long ago, my friend Rusty Dunagan, who is also a very close friend of my family, was grievously wounded in an IED explosion in Afghanistan losing his left arm and both legs.  Shortly thereafter, he became one of twenty-three American triple amputees from the war in Afghanistan.  Rusty was always this gritty, hard-working kid with a heart of gold—owing in part I suppose to his blue collar Irish-American roots. Rusty is a very courageous soldier, but more than that, he’s a REAL family man.  He and his lovely wife Angie have four children.  Having had the privilege to get to know Angie a lot over the last few months, I can say that without doubt, she is the sweetest girl in the world.  I absolutely love the Dunagan family and only want the very best for them, especially considering all the sacrifices they have had to make, for me, and for all of us. 

As a Veteran, I’m not blind to the current situation of the VA.  Though they have a lot of great folks working for them, they are over task-saturated and dismally under-funded.  Although Rusty is still a Sergeant on active duty in the Army until the completion of his medical boards, I fear that soon, he will join the staggering ranks of those not receiving the appropriate medical attention they need from the VA.  They do what they can, but let’s be very honest about this situation…it’s highly unlikely that the Army or the VA will ever be able to meet the Dunagan family’s needs.  So, we, The Gemini Project, have recorded our first full-length album (16 tracks in all!) with the intent that if we could raise enough money to be able to print the cd’s, we would sell them and donate ALL the proceeds to the Dunagan family.  That is precisely what we need your help to accomplish.  We need to raise $4,500 to meet album production costs for art, layout, design, photography and especially the cost to actually print the cd’s.  Please keep reading to find out how you can help us and become a part of The Gemini Project and this valuable cause.

Yakoke,

~KeL

 

What We Need & What You Get

The Gemini Project would be delighted to receive donations of any amount!  However, for every $25 donation you make, we will send you an autographed cd of our album, Ceallach, once it is released.

So what’s in it for you to donate to The Gemini Project cause?  Well, in addition to showing your support for our wounded Warriors, you'll also essentially be placing on reserve (or pre-ordering, if you will) a copy of our album BEFORE our release date.  Since quantities will be limited, this assures you will get a copy of "Ceallach" before they are gone.  But more important than anything else, you get to walk away feeling good about your purchase/donation knowing that all your money is going to an excellent cause.  When you think about it, a cd purchased in a music store will set you back $17.99…say you go in, blow out a twenty, then what do you do with the remaining two dollars?  Add five more, skip the cd store altogether, and donate to The Gemini Project! :) Not only will you get over an hour’s worth of some great, historically-rich music, (you can hear a couple of our tracks playing in the background in our video) but like the six of us musicians, you too will become part of The Gemini Project.  Nothing brings more soul satisfaction than giving of yourself to your community and thereby becoming a part of something bigger than yourself.  In essence, The Gemini project is just a really neat opportunity for all of us to be able to do that and to give something back.  It’s that pay-it-forward attitude…and it WILL all come back to you, believe me.

So let’s talk numbers:  Ah money, money…I hate money.  I think I speak for all our musicians when I say we have the heart for art’s sake, but no stomach for the business.  So, wouldn’t it be wonderful now if we could “pre-sell” all of our cd’s through your donations?  This is our hope, at any rate; it would mean a lot more funds for the Dunagan family and much less marketing headache for us.

We plan to print 1,000 cd’s.  We would like to keep only 15 of these, a free copy for all persons directly affiliated with album production and 1 for the Dunagans.  If we are able to “pre-sell” the remaining 985 (Lord willing) on this site through your donations, that’s $24,625.  If we meet our goal, IndieGoGo gets a 4% cut off the top and paypal takes 7% when the funds are distrubeted.  For a total of 11% reduction in fees, we now have $21,916.25. 

But to be able to print and distribute those cd’s in the first place, there are some upfront costs for album production.  We need to be able to pay our graphic artist designing our album cover and cd panels at least $500 because it’s just downright insulting if we don’t.  Photography will set us back another $450, and the cost to actually print the cd’s is $2,525 before tax.  In addition to this, my friend Rob Rebeck, chief engineer of Chapman Recording Studios, graciously volunteered to produce two tracks for us pro bono!  To show my appreciation, I’d like to be able to tip him $900 because that’s what he would ordinarily make for his services.  He’s a great guy, a brilliant musician, and has a family to support.  I really don’t want to take advantage of his kindness.  So, with all that being said, we are at $4,375 for album production costs.  We are using $4,500 as an estimate for album production costs in case there are unforeseen incidentals (like if the photographer commits highway robbery on us or something) and anything we don’t use directly for album production will be handed over to the Dunagan family along with the proceeds.  It bears repeating: NO GEMINI PROJECT MUSICIAN IS MAKING A DIME OFF THIS ALBUM.  And to be perfectly honest with you, we wouldn’t have it any other way.  :)

So before, I quoted the figure of $21,916.25.  Subtract $4,500 for album production costs (discussed above) and we now have $17,416.25.  Since all of you radiate awesomeness and our album sold out, we now have to ship those cd’s to you.  We estimate the cost of shipping to be $2 per unit.  Multiply that by 985 (for the number of cd’s sold) and shipping costs will set us back another $1,970.  Now for the part you’ve all been waiting for, if you help us pre-sell all 985 of our cd’s using this site with your $25 donations, $15,446.25 is what we would raise for the Dunagan family!  If you find yourself in a position to be able to make a donation, it would mean so much to all of us.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We totally understand that some folks just aren't in a position financially to be able to make a donation, but that doesn't mean that you can’t contribute to the cause!  If you could help us spread the word about The Gemini Project, either by word of mouth or utilizing your social networking tools, it would really mean a lot.  :))

Thanking you very much for your time, on behalf of The Gemini Project musicians,

Jim & KeL

story:
My name is Sophie Spreier, and I’m a cellist studying music performance. I have high hopes to become a professional collaborative musician on the stage and in the film industry, and I need your help.

 

Here is my story:

 

I’ve been playing the cello for most of my life. I started when I was three years old, studying the Suzuki Method with Carol Tarr in Denver, Colorado. My family moved to Pocatello, Idaho four years after and my single-parent mother commuted with me to Salt Lake City every week for lessons with Carey Cheney, a renowned Suzuki teacher, for the next 11 years. All the while, my mother raised her eight other children, survived breast cancer, endured a house fire, and established an independent Montessori school. She made sure that I was able to progress with my music, no matter what. Through the help of  her, my family, my dear mentors, and extraordinary circumstances, I’ve had the privilege of playing for legends including Arnold Steinhardt, Lawrence Lesser, and Yo-Yo Ma.

By the time I graduated high school, I knew I wanted to pursue an education and career in music. I auditioned for music programs at multiple colleges, and I was able to receive a full tuition scholarship from Utah State University in Logan, Utah. At the time, I was playing on my student cello that had survived our family’s house fire, but it was terribly smoke-damaged. I was playing at a level that surpassed my instrument, and I would eventually have to find a professional cello-- soon, if I wanted to progress.

The week before I was supposed to leave for school, my family and I were surprised with a visit from Ty Pennington and an “Extreme Makeover” of our burned-down home. Through the whirlwind of events and the inconceivable generosity of our community, my family and I were given the means to start our lives anew. I was also given a professional cello made by Chris Dungey-- something I’d dreamt about for years. 

 

Finding a bow:

 

Now that I have a high-quality cello, I’ve had to find a comparable bow because when it comes to stringed instruments, the bow is just as important as the instrument itself. I’ve been playing with my old student bow on a new Dungey cello, and the combination has actually been stunting the sound of my cello and my own technical development. Obviously I want to continue progressing, so I’ve been looking for bows comparable to my instrument. The process has been long and grueling because every bow is unique, and the match is different with every instrument. Weight, width, cut, density, country of origin, maker, year, and quality of materials are all factors that add into that distinction, then the instrument and playing style of the musician determine the match. 

 

Buying a bow:

 

After a year of investigating copious numbers of bows from multiple makers, I’ve finally found the perfect match for my beautiful cello. It’s an F. A. Nurnberger out of Germany in 1935 valued at $5000. I cannot find words enough to express how much relief this bow has given to my playing. I can finally reach that deep, rich tone my cello has been longing to produce, and I’ve improved immensely in my playing just after a few short months. 

Buying this bow is essentially the next step to my progression in a musical career. I’ve already taken out a student loan for the bow, but it will only cover half of the amount. I need to raise the other half in a very short amount of time. 

 

Study Abroad:

 

I’m in the third year of attaining my undergraduate degree, and I’ve been recruited to attend a 4-week study abroad program in England. It’s an opportunity that I feel could be crucial to my progressing as a musician. The program will cover music history and art courses crucial to my education as a musician and credited toward my degree. Not to mention, there will be opportunities to attend world-class concerts and museums across the breadth and width of England. I’ll also have the unique opportunity to take private lessons at conservatories including The Royal Academy of Music and Trinity Laban Conservatoire, as well as do a more in-depth study of Edward Elgar’s cello concerto in E Minor. 

I’ve been studying Elgar’s cello concerto over the past year, and I’ve fallen in-love with both the poignantly painful music and the era Elgar was living in at the time. I have a goal to perform an in-depth of study of this masterpiece while in England, and record it upon my return as part of a debut album in August 2013. 

Scholarships are available for the study abroad trip, but they are highly uncertain and could only cover up to $1000. The program plus airfare and basic needs will cost an estimated $5000; $6000 if I bring my cello with me and take additional private lessons.

 

Here is how you can help:

I have been working hard to save my own money to support these goals, but because I am a full-time student and musician, I'm not able to raise all the money myself. If you would like to contribute, any support (monetary or otherwise) is highly appreciated!
